subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Doclet
msgSnippet: Hi James Birchfield I have started with Implementing the Junit for EJB with the Example (jw-0526-testinfect.zip) which is available in Junit site. I am having
messageBody:
Hi James Birchfield


I have started with Implementing the Junit for EJB
with the Example (jw-0526-testinfect.zip) which is
available in Junit site. I am having hard time to get
it work with Weblogic. How can i launch the Junit
Testrunner with weblogic.

Thankyou
Prasanna



--- jbirchfield@... wrote:
> All,
> I have started using some code internally and
> would like to run the
> idea past the JUnit group as a whole. We know the
> value of performing test
> cases, we just seldom actually take the time to
> implement them in our
> hectic schedule. So I have put together the frame
> work for automatically
> generating test cases for any class, any method.
> Here is a sample Java
> file:
>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> package test;
>
> /**
> * @testable
> */
> public class DocletTest {
>
> public DocletTest() {
> }
>
> /**
> * @test-method
> * @test-case 4
> * @assert 16
> * @test-case 5
> * @assert 25
> * @test-case 6
> * @assert 36
> */
> public int square(int a) {
> return a*a;
> }
>
> /**
> * @test-method
> * @test-case "Hello World!"
> * @assert "!dlroW olleH"
> */
> public String reverse(String a) {
> char[] temp = new char[a.length()];
> char[] orig = a.toCharArray();
> int j = 0;
> for(int i = orig.length-1; i >= 0; i--) {
> temp[j++] = orig[i];
> }
> return new String(temp);
> }
> }
>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> Using the Doclet API, special javadoc tags are
> placed throughout the code.
> The first tag '@testable' indicates that we want a
> test case generated.
> The Doclet then scans the methods and will generate
> a testxxx method for
> each method with an '@test-method' tag. The
> '@test-case xxx' and '@assert
> xxx' tags work together as the input to your method,
> and the expected
> output. So the result of processing this file is as
> follows:
>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> /**
> * Generated TestSuite for DocletTest. Do not edit!
> */
> package test;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import junit.extensions.*;
>
>
> public class DocletTestTestCase extends TestCase {
>
> DocletTest test;
>
> public DocletTestTestCase(String name) {
> super(name);
> }
>
> public static void main(String[] args) {
> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> return new TestSuite(DocletTestTestCase.class);
> }
>
> protected void setUp() {
> }
>
> protected void tearDown() {}
>
>
> public void testsquare() {
>
> try {
> test = new DocletTest();
> int a = 4;
>
> int returntype = test.square(a);
>
> assert(returntype == 16);
>
> }
> catch(Exception e) {
> fail("Could not invoke method square on
> test.DocletTestTestCase.");
> }
>
> try {
> test = new DocletTest();
> int a = 5;
>
> int returntype = test.square(a);
>
> assert(returntype == 25);
>
> }
> catch(Exception e) {
> fail("Could not invoke method square on
> test.DocletTestTestCase.");
> }
>
> try {
> test = new DocletTest();
> int a = 6;
>
> int returntype = test.square(a);
>
> assert(returntype == 36);
>
> }
> catch(Exception e) {
> fail("Could not invoke method square on
> test.DocletTestTestCase.");
> }
>
> }
>
> public void testreverse() {
>
> try {
> test = new DocletTest();
> java.lang.String a = "Hello World!";
>
> java.lang.String returntype =
> test.reverse(a);
>
> assert(returntype.equals("!dlroW olleH"));
>
> }
> catch(Exception e) {
> fail("Could not invoke method reverse on
> test.DocletTestTestCase.");
> }
>
> }
>
>
> }
>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
> I have several more ideas for the above, but wanted
> to share the basics and
> see if anyone was interested in it. This started
> out as a project to test
> our EJB's(and still does) generating all of the
> lookup code, and providing
> he method level testing of all our EJB's.
>
> If any interest is generated, I would be more than
> happy to package up what
> I have so far and share it....
>
> James Birchfield
>
